A law of composition on a set $M$ is commutative if $ab = ba$ for all elements $a, b \in M$.
The order of a group $G$, denoted as ord $G$, is defined as the number of elements in $G$ if $G$ is finite. If $G$ is infinite, its order is said to be infinite.
The pair (S, R), where S is a subring of R, is called a ring extension.

A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an isomorphism if it admits an inverse, i.e., there exists a ring homomorphism $\psi: R' \longrightarrow R$ such that $\psi \circ \varphi=\mathrm{id}_{R}$ and $\varphi \circ \psi=\mathrm{id}_{R'}$. This is equivalent to $\varphi$ being bijective.

An integral domain $R$ is called a Euclidean domain if it admits a map $\delta: R-\{0\} \longrightarrow \mathbb{N}$ making possible Euclidean division in $R$ in the following sense: Given elements $f, g \in R, g \neq 0$, there are elements $q, r \in R$ such that $f=q g+r$, where $\delta(r)<\delta(g)$ or $r=0$.

For an integral domain $R$, the field of fractions $Q(R)$ is the set of equivalence classes of pairs $(a, b)$ where $a, b \in R$ and $b \neq 0$, under the equivalence relation defined by $(a, b) \sim (a', b')$ if and only if $ab' = a'b$.
The length l_A(M) of an A-module M is defined as the supremum of all numbers l such that there is a chain of submodules 0 subsetneq M_1 subsetneq M_2 subsetneq ... subsetneq M_l = M of length l.
A field extension $K \subset L$ is called simple if there exists an element $\alpha \in L$ such that $L=K(\alpha)$. The degree $[K(\alpha): K]$ is referred to as the degree of $\alpha$ over $K$.

An algebraic closure $\\[\overline{\mathbb{F}}_p\]$ of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ is a field that contains $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ and all its algebraic extensions. It is used to view the fields $\\[\mathbb{F}_{p^n}\]$ as subfields.

An ideal \(\mathfrak{a}\) in a ring \(R\) is called reduced if \(\mathfrak{a} = \operatorname{rad} \mathfrak{a}\), where \(\operatorname{rad} \mathfrak{a}\) is the set of all elements \(a \in R\) such that there exists some \(n \in \mathbb{N}\) with \(a^{n} \in \mathfrak{a}\).
An element of a set is an object belonging to a set.
The image of a function \( f: A 	o B \) is the set of all elements in \( B \) that have at least one corresponding element in \( A \) via the function \( f \).
